subject: optflags: set _FORTIFY_SOURCE for preproc
commitMessage:
optflags: set _FORTIFY_SOURCE for preproc

Without it will fail if optflags are not overridden
and raise an error like :

  configure: CFLAGS error: CFLAGS may only be used to specify C compiler flags, not macro definitions. Use CPPFLAGS for: -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2
  configure: error: Can not continue. Fix errors mentioned immediately above this line.
  error: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.AoOYbS (%build)

More details at :

https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc-4.9.2/gcc/Preprocessor-Options.html#index-Wp-986

Change-Id: I49c8545a0526a1922905ef55de3a59edf9036068
Signed-off-by: Philippe Coval <philippe.coval@open.eurogiciel.org>

subject: replace obsoleted "find -perm +NNN" syntax
commitMessage:
replace obsoleted "find -perm +NNN" syntax

This patch is required when we use findutils-4.5.14 version. When we
tried to upgrade the findutils to 4.5.14 version, I've got below error
because the version of findutils obsoleted "find -perm +NNN".

[  146s] find: invalid mode '+111'
[  146s] error: Bad exit status from /var/tmp/rpm-tmp.5tcK7o (%install)

I picked up this patch from openSUSE[1] to solve this problem.

Origin: mail@bernhard-voelker.de

- replace obsoleted "find -perm +NNN" syntax [bnc#842004]
  to "-perm /NNN" in debugsource-package.diff and
  finddebuginfo.diff.

[1]: https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/200349

Change-Id: I38394427e4a806111550ad8ee560a448dd7a7307
Signed-off-by: Chanho Park <chanho61.park@samsung.com>

errors. With the tag removed from the macro the packages inherit their
parents' groups which makes rpmlint happy.

subject: MSM: Avoid creating empty access rule files
commitMessage:
MSM: Avoid creating empty access rule files

The msm plugin creates one access rule file
in SMACK_RULES_PATH=/etc/smack/accesses.d for
each RPM installed.

Since Tizen 3, the guideline for packages is
simplified and the new guideline states that
manifest files have to be as simple as:

<manifest>
 <request>
    <domain name="_"/>
 </request>
</manifest>

It means that most access rule files are empty.

Thus, this patch removes the file if it is empty
because without any penality, it improves:
 - the start time of the system
 - the administration of the system

The start time is improved because at start, all
the files in /etc/smack/accesses.d are read and
loaded to the kernel. As empty files are just removed,
no time is spend to seek it, open it, read it, close it,
apply empty rule.

The administration is also improved because only meaning
access rule files are retains, avoid to have to sort what
is meaning and what is not.

Change-Id: I7b40f2b291f0c1dbcb2f033f62191c651430e3c8
Signed-off-by: José Bollo <jose.bollo@open.eurogiciel.org>

subject: Allow re-execution of the %prep section
commitMessage:
Allow re-execution of the %prep section

With Yocto, when building rpm a second time, the do_prep() function
fails because it assumes it hasn't already ran but will be re-using the
previous build directory which hasn't been cleaned. This patch prevent
such a situation to fail.

This issue is not present when building with GBS since every new build
is made in a clean directory but since the yocto recipes are generated
from spec file, it is better to directly correct the spec file.
This patch has no impact on the GBS build.

Bug-Tizen: BTY-15
Change-Id: I1e992b63b41ae76a4d6706046e741dc2d25b15eb
Signed-off-by: Kévin THIERRY <kevin.thierry@open.eurogiciel.org>

subject: Update changelog
commitMessage:
Update changelog

Change-Id: Ice517533b3a0650f6d99c1e8e21e73d3c9b4c178
Signed-off-by: Patrick McCarty <patrick.mccarty@linux.intel.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.
Patch Set 1: Verified+1
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I agree with Artem[1] that there is no point in pushing updates to changelog to gerrit.

[1] https://lists.tizen.org/pipermail/dev/2014-January/001720.html

Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Lukasz, there is no _official_ statement that would require pushing .changes bypassing gerrit so I do not agree with your review.

Please also note that that Patrick is listed as one of maintainers...

Patch Set 1:

I generally agree with Artem's points from that email, in particular how changelogs should be maintained, the purpose of changelogs compared to git history, how developers/integrators fit in. But I don't see a strong argument for not submitting changelogs for review, or vice versa.

If the step to push changelogs for review is optional, this complicates workflow, bookkeeping done by the Tizen tools/infrastructure, etc. For example, the tools currently expect that the SR'ed commit is reviewed and merged through gerrit, as seen with the robot OBS SR messages.

I think that either the changelog review should be required, or maintainers should push the changelogs directly to the tizen branch, not a choice between the two. The latter process would work even better if the Tizen tools can adapt to make the process easier (e.g. gbs changelog-submit, or similar).

Patch Set 1:

Until there is an official documented process in place for .changes maintenance, I will use discretion in whether or not changelog updates should be submitted for review or pushed directly.
Change has been successfully merged into the git repository.

subject: Export kernel package name and kernel package release as new macros.
commitMessage:
Export kernel package name and kernel package release as new macros.

The following macros have been added:
  1. %kernel_name    - kernel name
  2. %kernel_release - kenrel release

Change-Id: Ie3d2b310b839353af2855f1b6a0eff6abff1aeeb
Signed-off-by: Jacek Pielaszkiewicz <j.pielaszkie@samsung.com>

comments.message: Uploaded patch set 1.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Patch Set 1:

The macro is intended to get kernel name. My intention is to provide set of macros that allow avoid use hardcoded names in spec files for external kernel modules. See as example "profile/ivi/OpenAVB" repository. Hardcoded defines at the top of the file

%define kernel kernel-x86-ivi    
%define kernel_relstr "%(/bin/rpm -q --queryformat '%{VERSION}-%{RELEASE}' %{kernel})"
%define kernel_release %(echo %{kernel_relstr})
%define kernel_modstr "%(/bin/rpm -ql %{kernel} | sort | grep /lib/modules/%{kernel_release} | head -1 | sed 's#/*$##g')"
%define kernel_modpath %(echo %{kernel_modstr})
%define kernel_moddir  %(echo %{kernel_modstr} | sed 's#.*/##g')

can be replace by:


%define kernel %kernel_devel_package_name
%define kernel_relstr %kernel_devel_package_release
%define kernel_release %kernel_devel_package_release
%define kernel_modstr /lib/modules/%{kernel_devel_uname_r}
%define kernel_modpath /lib/modules/%{kernel_devel_uname_r}
%define kernel_moddir  %{kernel_devel_uname_r}
Uploaded patch set 2.

Patch Set 2:

> The macro is intended to get kernel name. My intention is to provide set of macros that allow avoid use hardcoded names in spec files for external kernel modules. See as example "profile/ivi/OpenAVB" repository. Hardcoded defines at the top of the file

Understood. The macros will definitely simplify the openavb spec, and others as well.

Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Looks okay.
Patch Set 2: Verified+1

subject: tizen: Export kernel-devel's package version as %kernel_devel_uname_r
commitMessage:
tizen: Export kernel-devel's package version as %kernel_devel_uname_r

This macro provides full version string of available kernel headers
as provided by kernel-devel package.

This functionality should simplify process of packaging additional
external kernel modules eliminating the step of manual searching
for appropriate kernel build directory, eg.

  BuildRequires: kernel-devel

  %build
  make M=/lib/modules/%{kernel_devel_uname_r}/build modules

Change-Id: Iea73e418065068f8451c42a2a3a4b46a9b5ffaac
Signed-off-by: Karol Lewandowski <k.lewandowsk@samsung.com>

subject: MSM: fix access type length and validation
commitMessage:
MSM: fix access type length and validation

This patch fixes three issues with access type:

- SMACK_ACCESS_TYPE_LENGHT -> SMACK_ACCESS_TYPE_LENGTH
- Changed the value of SMACK_ACCESS_TYPE_LENGTH from 5 to 6.
- String length was calculated with unsafe 'strlen()'. Changed to
  use strlen(type, SMACK_LABEL_LENGTH + 1) instead.

Change-Id: I127d7b2beb8a3258ec1e4a5142f253f842b2fa7a
Signed-off-by: Jarkko Sakkinen <jarkko.sakkinen@linux.intel.com>

subject: Security plugin: change policy to advisory
commitMessage:
Security plugin: change policy to advisory

Change policy from enforcing to advisory when access is requested
from unknown domain or permitted to unknown domain. Also trunacated
lines to 80 characters, fixed grammar in the warning messages, and
removed trailing spaces and tabs.

In future, it might make sense to make this behaviour a command-line
option. Added a FIXME comment about that.

Change-Id: Iab78d79a8a28e019ec8601265a59d259fd46f9d6
Signed-off-by: Jarkko Sakkinen <jarkko.sakkinen@linux.intel.com>

comments.message:
Patch Set 1:

[BUILD CHECK RESULT] This change is built against OBS project Tizen: 

 repository     arch           result         

 standard       armv7hl        succeeded      

 standard       x86_64         succeeded      

 standard       armv7l         succeeded      

 standard       i586           succeeded
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 1:

I'd like to have some question about this. 
Firstly we prefer to make a patch set and add this in the spec file if the source codes come from outside. is there any reason you modify the code directly?
Secondly, if this is really needed to remove the unneeded function, I think it's better to contribute this changes both mainstream and ours. 
Thirdly, if the unneeded function is exported function, you need to build all the dependent packages as well. if it is not, you can use "--gc-section" link option instead to remove the function

Patch Set 1:

Answers:

> Firstly we prefer to make a patch set and add this in the >spec file if the source codes come from outside. is there >any reason you modify the code directly? 

The modification addresses the plugin code and not rpm code directly. Since all the code for plugin and hooks are currently included in the tree without a patch set, I don't see a reason for making this particular change as a patch. 

>Secondly, if this is really needed to remove the unneeded >function, I think it's better to contribute this changes >both mainstream and ours. 

The function that is removed is from plugin source code, which isn't part of upstream rpm. So, no contribution to upstream is possible in this case. 

>Thirdly, if the unneeded function is exported function, >you need to build all the dependent packages as well. if >it is not, you can use "--gc-section" link option instead >to remove the function

It isn't an exported function and not used by anyone apart from the rpm security plugin (and even plugin doens't use it)
Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 1:

> Firstly we prefer to make a patch set and add this in the >spec file if the source codes come from outside. is there >any reason you modify the code directly?

We do not support external patches anymore, all code is managed in the tizen branch based on upstream. GBS generates the patches and adds them to the spec file. That is how all upstream packages are managed right now. Try this with the gbs export on some upstream git trees from tizen 3.0

that change copied the file from the bootstrap or the host system which has a modified device policy file listing packages from the running system. We need to copy a vanilla version of the file, not one which is being used and was altered.

Patch Set 5:

Ok, this is a valid point: we don't want packages form host system. The question is where to get this default policy file? Currently it isn't stored anywhere and after it is installed, it will be updated with each installation.

Now in the latest commit, the plugin rpm has the default policy file, which is later copied to rpm chroot. Also, now all policy paths are configured with the help of rpm macros, so no hardcoding anymore.

Patch Set 8:

on a tizen system, this is how I test this change:

I build the package locally and install it on my tizen system (for example IVI, PC or even the common image with e17)

zypper -R /tmp/xx  ar http://download.tizen.org/snapshots/tizen/common/latest/repos/tizen/x86_64/packages/ tizen

then I do:

zypper -R /tmp/xx  in systemd


and then check contents of /tmp/xx/etc/device-sec-policy

Patch Set 8: Verified-1

device policy file is not being updated with new package installs

Patch Set 8:

I'm wondering, how QA testing is passing if such major functionality of rpm security plugin is not working ?

Patch Set 8:

Verified+1 should be for the actual change and not be set for running generic test cases that have no coverage for the change itself.

Patch Set 8: -Verified

Yeah, let's blame everything on QA! It's just one quy, we can take him! Quick, to the pitchforks!

While you're absolutely right, of course, that everything has to be tested thoroughly and in every conceivable situation, I do miss some things too.(shocker!) 

But let's not forget that bugs have to be introduced by devel in the first place ;) 

It's not an excuse, of course, just pointing out the present reality. We miss things. Thank you for politely pointing them out!
Uploaded patch set 9.

Patch Set 9:

Ok, here is the new patch. Let's not blame the QA: we don't have tests now on --root option and it wasn't doing the right thing only when run with --root. 

Mihai, I think we need more rpm tests to our suite. You should be able to do run exactly the same set of tests with --root=/sometmpdir option. Let's discuss the tests tomorrow. Now i have just tested it manually and for me it works with --root: policy is in the right place and it gets modified.

Patch Set 9:

Mihai, please run the tests as Elena suggests.  I'd like to see if things are passing before I review.

Patch Set 9:

Elena, nobody is blaming QA. We just need to make sure that changes are verified correctly. Running the tests is good because it tells us nothing is broken because of that change, but we also need to verify the change itself and that achieves the desired results. I suggest to use my method for testing.
Uploaded patch set 10.

Patch Set 10: Verified+1

Everything should work as expected. But, as usual, feel free to prove me wrong... QA is a zilch.
Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 10:

hmm, now when I try to build this in gbs with a previously bult binary, I get this:

[    4s] preinstalling rpm...
[    4s] installing rpm-4.11.0.1-100
[    4s] error: Failed to expand transaction_msm_runtime_policy macro
[    4s] exit ...

there is something wrong.


We need to make sure this rpm does not break builds in gbs and obs, so need some more testing!

Patch Set 10:

What do you mean by "previously installed binary"?
In one of the previous version of patch, I was using "transaction_msm_runtime_policy" macros to define runtime location of the policy, but in the latest version, I switched back to hardcoded path for it since Sasha pointed out that macros can be redifined via command line in rpm. 

So, now I don't use that macro anymore. But that code with macro has never been merged to anywhere, so how could it make a problem?

Patch Set 10:

Hi Anas,

Could you please provide the repo you are using during gbs build since we can not replicate your problem with the following repos:
for x86_64: https://download.tz.otcshare.org/releases/daily/trunk/pc/latest/
for i586: https://download.tizen.org/snapshots/tizen/mobile/latest

I also tried to change the rpm package in order to use this build to build another rpm. Again, no issues.

Patch Set 10: Code-Review+2

ok, I see the code in question being removed now. thanks for the clarification.
